title: Q2 Checkpoint: Congruence & Right Triangles
description: Cumulative quarterly assessment covering Units 3-4: triangle congruence postulates (SSS, SAS, ASA, AAS, HL), CPCTC, congruence proofs, Pythagorean Theorem and its converse, special right triangles (45-45-90 and 30-60-90), and introductory trig ratios with real-world applications.

remediationResources.reteachFocus: SSS (3 sides), SAS (2 sides + included angle), ASA (2 angles + included side); 'included' means between the other two parts
AAS (2 angles + non-included side), HL (right triangle hypotenuse + leg only), SSA fails (ambiguous case)
Used AFTER proving congruence, not before; correspondence from congruence statement order
Two-column format, common reasons (reflexive, midpoint, vertical angles, bisector), proof flow
a²+b²=c², identify hypotenuse first (longest, opposite right angle), recognize common triples and multiples
Compare a²+b² to c²: equal→right, greater→acute, less→obtuse; always test with c as longest side
45-45-90 ratio 1:1:√2, 30-60-90 ratio 1:√3:2, work from any given side to find others
SOH-CAH-TOA, opposite/adjacent change with reference angle, angle of elevation/depression setups

assessmentProblems.question: Two triangles have three pairs of congruent sides. Name the congruence postulate.
In two right triangles, the hypotenuses are congruent and one pair of legs is congruent. Name the congruence theorem.
assessmentProblems.answer: HL (Hypotenuse-Leg). Only works for right triangles.

assessmentProblems.question: Explain why SSA is NOT a valid method for proving triangle congruence. Give a specific example.
assessmentProblems.answer: SSA (two sides and a non-included angle) can produce two different triangles—the ambiguous case. For example, with sides 5 and 8 and an angle of 30° opposite the side of 5, the longer side can 'swing' to two positions, creating two non-congruent triangles with the same SSA information.

assessmentProblems.question: △ABC ≅ △XYZ by SAS. If AB = 14, ∠A = 50°, and BC = 9, find XY, ∠X, and YZ.
assessmentProblems.answer: A↔X, B↔Y, C↔Z (by correspondence). XY = AB = 14, ∠X = ∠A = 50°, YZ = BC = 9.

assessmentProblems.question: A right triangle has legs of 8 and 15. Find the hypotenuse.
A triangle has sides 7, 24, and 25. Determine if it is a right triangle and explain.
assessmentProblems.answer: 7² + 24² = 49 + 576 = 625 = 25². Since a²+b² = c², it IS a right triangle. (7-24-25 is a Pythagorean triple.)

assessmentProblems.question: In a 45-45-90 triangle, the hypotenuse measures 18. Find the length of each leg.
In a 30-60-90 triangle, the side opposite the 60° angle is 5√3. Find the short leg and hypotenuse.
assessmentProblems.answer: Long leg = short × √3, so short leg = 5√3/√3 = 5. Hypotenuse = 2 × 5 = 10. Verify: 5² + (5√3)² = 25 + 75 = 100 = 10² ✓.

assessmentProblems.question: In a right triangle, the side opposite angle θ is 7 and the hypotenuse is 25. Find sin(θ), cos(θ), and the adjacent side.
A surveyor stands 100 feet from the base of a building and measures the angle of elevation to the top as 40°. How tall is the building? Round to the nearest foot. (tan 40° ≈ 0.8391)
assessmentProblems.answer: tan(40°) = height/100. Height = 100 × tan(40°) ≈ 100 × 0.8391 ≈ 84 feet. We use tangent because we have the adjacent side (100 ft) and need the opposite side (height).

spiralReview.question: SPIRAL (Triangle Inequality): Can sides of length 5, 9, and 15 form a triangle? Explain.
spiralReview.answer: No. 5 + 9 = 14, and 14 < 15. The sum of the two shortest sides does not exceed the longest, so these cannot form a triangle.

spiralReview.question: SPIRAL (Angle Pairs): Two supplementary angles measure (4x + 5)° and (6x + 15)°. Find x and both angle measures.
